questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician in June for a routine check-up. She has chronic back pain and underwent an appendectomy at the age of 27. Her last mammogram was 6 months ago and showed no abnormalities. Her last Pap smear was 2 years ago and unremarkable. A colonoscopy 5 years ago was normal. She regularly attends water aerobic classes and physical therapy for her back pain. Her mother died of breast cancer last year and her father has arterial hypertension. She is married and has two children. The patient recently got back from a cruise to Mexico where she celebrated her 40th wedding anniversary. She takes a multivitamin daily and uses topical steroids. Her immunization records show that she has never received a pneumococcal or a shingles vaccine, her last tetanus booster was 6 years ago, and her last influenza vaccine was 2 years ago. She drinks one to two alcoholic beverages every weekend. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 72 kg (160 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 124/70 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteoporosis screening is performed with dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA). The bone density scan is recommended for postmenopausal women older than 65 years of age, or younger postmenopausal women with a pathological fracture or other risk factors for osteoporosis (e.g., positive family history).

B) INCORRECT:

The CDC recommends pneumococcal vaccination for adults ≥ 50 years of age. However, the polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23) is typically recommended after administering a pneumococcal conjugate vaccine, which this patient has not yet received.

C) INCORRECT:

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). A colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Because this patient had her last colonoscopy 5 years ago, which was normal, and lacks symptoms suggestive of colorectal cancer (e.g., weight loss, hematochezia), a colonoscopy is not indicated at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

A Pap smear is recommended every 3 years in women 21–65 years of age (or even better for patients 30–65 years of age, HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years). This woman had a normal Pap smear 2 years ago.

E) INCORRECT:

Because influenza viruses are constantly evolving, the influenza vaccine composition is reviewed, and a newly updated vaccine is released (and recommended) for every flu season (∼ Oct.–Apr. in the northern hemisphere). This patient should return again in the early fall for an influenza vaccine.

F) CORRECT:

The CDC currently recommends the recombinant zoster vaccine for the prevention of herpes zoster (shingles) and its related complications. The recombinant zoster vaccine (administered in 2 doses, 2–6 months apart) is recommended for all immunocompetent adults ≥ 50 years of age, regardless of a history of shingles, and for adults ≥ 19 years of age who are or will become immunodeficient or immunosuppressed due to disease or therapy.

Additionally, this individual should receive pneumococcal vaccination with a pneumococcal conjugate vaccine.
questions.hint: The correct choice is recommended in all patients over 50 years by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has no history of serious illness. Menopause occurred 7 years ago. Colonoscopy 4 years ago disclosed no abnormalities. A serum lipid profile obtained last year was within the reference range. Two years ago, a Pap smear with testing for human papillomavirus showed no abnormalities. Mammography performed 10 months ago showed no abnormalities. She is a retired university professor and lives with her husband. She has no children. Her father developed colon cancer at the age of 75 years. She has no family history of hip fracture. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 58 kg (128 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A fasting serum glucose level is 102 mg/dL. Screening for depression with a validated questionnaire is negative. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?

choices.text: No specific health maintenance recommendation is needed

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening mammography every 2 years in women aged 40–74 years with average risk for breast cancer. This patient had a normal mammogram 10 months ago, so she does not require further screening at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

Screening for lipid disorders is recommended in all adults aged 20–75 years at least every 4–6 years. In adults aged 40–75 years, the screening interval can be shortened based on the individual ASCVD risk. Given that this patient had a normal serum lipid profile 1 year ago and has no significant risk factors for cardiovascular disease (e.g., history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, or smoking), her ASCVD risk is likely low. A repeat serum lipid profile is not warranted at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). Colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Individuals with a first-degree relative (FDR) with a history of colorectal cancer, like this patient, are generally recommended to obtain screening more frequently (every 5 years) and start earlier (40 years of age or 10 years before the youngest FDR's age at diagnosis). Because her last colonoscopy 4 years ago was normal and she lacks symptoms suggestive of colorectal cancer (e.g., weight loss, hematochezia), she does not require repeat screening at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening women ≥ 65 years of age for osteoporosis with bone measurement testing (e.g., dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry). For postmenopausal women < 65 years of age, the decision to screen should be based on an assessment of the patient's overall risk for osteoporosis. This patient has no significant risk factors for osteoporosis (e.g., family history of hip fracture, smoking, alcohol consumption, low BMI), so screening is not indicated at this time.

E) CORRECT:

No specific health maintenance recommendation is needed at this time for this 61-year-old woman who is currently up to date with all recommended screening tests based on her age, history, and physical examination findings. The recommendations that this patient has followed include screening for cervical cancer (Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing every 5 years), colon cancer (every 5 years in patients with a first-degree relative with a history of colorectal cancer, every 10 years in the general population), and breast cancer (mammography every 1–2 years). Moreover, she does not have identifiable risk factors for cardiovascular disease (e.g., history of dyslipidemia, diabetes, hypertension, or smoking) or osteoporosis (e.g., family history of hip fracture, smoking, alcohol consumption, low BMI), which would warrant enhanced screening for these conditions.

See “Screening recommendations for nonpregnant women by age” table.

F) INCORRECT:

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening women between 30 and 65 years of age for cervical cancer using any of the following strategies: every 3 years with cervical cytology, every 5 years with testing for high-risk human papillomavirus (hrHPV) testing, or every 5 years with hrHPV testing in combination with cytology. This patient had a normal Pap smear with testing for human papillomavirus 2 years ago, so she does not require further screening at this time.
questions.hint: This patient's history and physical examination findings do not suggest that she has a higher risk of morbidity than average.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the office as a new patient. She recently moved to the area. She feels well. She has dyslipidemia treated with pravastatin. Her past three Pap smears have shown no abnormalities; the most recent Pap smear was 2 years ago. Her maternal aunt was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 56 years. The patient smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years but quit 10 years ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms consistently. She is 155 cm (5 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. Her pulse is 68/min, and blood pressure is 129/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate health maintenance recommendation at this time?

choices.text: Obtain low-dose CT scan of the chest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

For cervical cancer screening in women 30–65 years of age, the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends Pap smears every 3 years with cervical cytology alone, every 5 years with human papillomavirus (HPV) testing alone, or every 5 years with HPV testing in combination with cytology (HPV/Pap cotesting). This 38-year-old patient had a normal Pap smear 2 years ago and therefore does not need further testing at this time.

B) CORRECT:

Measurement of fasting blood glucose (FBG) concentration is routinely used to screen for diabetes mellitus (DM). Although screening recommendations for DM differ among expert groups, this 38-year-old patient with dyslipidemia and a BMI of 29 kg/m2 meets the screening criteria of both the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) and the American Diabetes Association (ADA). The USPSTF recommends screening individuals 35–70 years of age with overweight or obesity. The ADA recommends screening all individuals ≥ 35 years of age and individuals < 35 years of age who: have overweight or obesity and ≥ 1 additional risk factor for T2DM; have a history of prediabetes or gestational diabetes; or have any risk-enhancing comorbidities (e.g., HIV infection, cystic fibrosis, post organ transplantation).

Besides FBG, other tests used to screen for DM include hemoglobin A1C (HbA1C) and the oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT). Each of the following findings can be used to establish a diagnosis of diabetes mellitus: FBG ≥ 126 mg/dL, HbA1C ≥ 6.5%, and a 2-hour plasma glucose ≥ 200 mg/dL during an OGTT.

C) INCORRECT:

Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) screening with abdominal ultrasonography can be considered in individuals < 65 years of age who have multiple risk factors for AAA or a family history of AAA, neither of which applies to this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

An annual low-dose CT scan of the chest is indicated for lung cancer screening in individuals aged 50–80 years with a smoking history of ≥ 20 pack years. This patient has a smoking history of 10 pack years and therefore does not require screening at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Breast cancer screening is generally not recommended before 40 years of age (except for individuals at high risk of breast cancer). Additionally, when breast cancer screening is appropriate, screening mammography is the recommended screening modality, not breast ultrasonography. Breast ultrasonography is typically reserved for individuals < 30 years of age with a palpable breast mass or other findings concerning for breast cancer.

F) INCORRECT:

In individuals 19–49 years of age, pneumococcal vaccination is only indicated if there are risk factors for invasive pneumococcal disease. Because this 38-year-old patient only has dyslipidemia and a remote history of smoking, she does not need the pneumococcal vaccine at this time.
questions.hint: This patient's dyslipidemia and overweight put her at risk of developing a chronic medical condition that can cause microvascular damage.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician for counseling prior to conception. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 12 g/dL and a 2-h postprandial serum glucose concentration of 160 mg/dL (N < 140). The physician recommends oral supplementation of folic acid starting at least 4 weeks prior to conception to reduce the risk of neural tube defects in a newborn. Which of the following recommendations is an example of the same category of prevention?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Regular blood pressure measurement is an example of secondary prevention because its purpose is the early detection of hypertension in an asymptomatic individual in order to promote early intervention and to prevent further progression and complications from the disease. The recommendation provided to this patient belongs to a different category of disease prevention.

B) INCORRECT:

Papanicolau smear is an example of secondary prevention because its purpose is the early detection of cervical cancer in an asymptomatic woman in order to promote early intervention and to prevent further progression and complications from the disease. In relation to cervical cancer, vaccination against HPV in young, sexually active individuals is an example of a recommendation that belong to the same category as the recommendation provided to this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

HIV-1/2 combination immunoassay is an example of secondary prevention because its purpose is the early detection of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) in an asymptomatic person in order to promote early intervention and to prevent further progression and complications from the disease. In relation to HIV infection, the use of condoms, HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis, HIV postexposure prophylaxis, and antiretroviral therapy in HIV-positive pregnant women to prevent vertical transmission are examples of recommendations that belong to the same category as that of the recommendation provided to this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Insulin therapy is an example of tertiary prevention, which aims to reduce the mortality and morbidity of a disease that is clinically symptomatic or already been diagnosed by laboratory studies. This asymptomatic patient with a 2-hour postprandial glucose of 160 mg/dL could have impaired glucose tolerance (prediabetes) but she does not require insulin therapy, which is only indicated for patients with diabetes mellitus (2-hour postprandial glucose ≥ 200 mg/dL). The recommendation for folic acid supplementation belongs to a different category of disease prevention.

E) CORRECT:

Folic acid supplementation and moderate aerobic exercise are both examples of primary prevention. Performing moderate aerobic exercise is an example of a lifestyle modification that decreases the risk of developing diseases like hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and metabolic syndrome. Other examples of primary prevention measures include vaccinations to prevent infections, seat belt laws to prevent injury from a motor vehicle collision, and brushing with fluoridation of toothpaste to prevent dental caries.

F) INCORRECT:

Breast self-examination is an example of secondary prevention because its purpose is the early detection of breast cancer in an asymptomatic woman in order to promote early intervention and to prevent further progression and complications from the disease. In relation to breast cancer, risk-reducing mastectomy in individuals with BRCA mutations, breastfeeding during the postpartum period, weight loss, and smoking cessation are examples of recommendations that belong to the same category as the recommendation provided by the physician to this patient.
questions.hint: The prevention of disease before it occurs is referred to as primary prevention.

questions.text: A 36-year-old Native American man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. The patient is married, has 4 children, and works as a software engineer. His father died in a car accident and his mother has coronary artery disease. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. He appears healthy. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 92 kg (203 lbs); his BMI is 28 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 121/78 mm Hg on the right arm and 122/80 mm Hg on the left. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement by the physician regarding health maintenance at this visit?

choices.text: “At this time, there is nothing to worry about. Have a great day.”
“I would like to discuss screening options for high blood sugar with you today.”
“I would like to perform a fecal occult blood test on a stool sample.”
“Please fill out a short questionnaire about addictions before you leave today.”
“I suggest we do a 24-hour blood pressure measurement to evaluate you for hypertension.”

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation is normal as he has no complaints and a normal physical examination. However, Native American ancestry is associated with an increased risk for certain conditions, and patients within this population should receive the corresponding counseling and screening necessary. Furthermore, it is recommended that, prior to the end of the visit, the physician reminds the patient to schedule an appropriate follow-up appointment.

B) CORRECT:

The American Diabetes Association (ADA) recommends screening for type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in individuals ≥ 35 years of age regardless of risk factors and in individuals < 35 years of age with either overweight or obesity and ≥ 1 additional risk factor for T2DM (e.g., first-degree family history, certain race or ethnicity, hypertension). The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for T2DM in asymptomatic individuals 35–70 years of age with overweight or obesity. As per both guidelines, screening this patient for T2DM is recommended.

Native American individuals have the highest prevalence of T2DM among racial and ethnic groups in the United States as a result of genetic and socioeconomic factors. While smoking, diet, and alcohol use are risk factors that are generally assessed in routine health maintenance examinations, social and genetic determinants of health are less commonly assessed, often because of poor access to care and provider negligence of minority groups. Poor screening consequently contributes to a higher burden of disease among various racial and ethnic minorities (e.g., African Americans, Hispanics, and Asian Americans).

C) INCORRECT:

While there is a correlation between higher rates of colorectal cancer and Native American ancestry, the causes of this are complex and not fully established. Inequities in access to colorectal screening may be the primary driver for this disparity. The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). Colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Since this patient is only 36 years of age and does not have significant risk factors for colorectal cancer, screening is not currently indicated. In addition, it is inappropriate to tell this patient he has a high risk of malignancy without providing context, as it will likely increase patient anxiety.

D) INCORRECT:

While recreational drug and alcohol use are a matter of concern in Native American communities, it is inappropriate to assume an addiction from this patient's race alone. The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends that all adults should be screened for excessive alcohol use, but since this patient reports not drinking alcohol or taking recreational drugs, additional screening is unwarranted. Moreover, physicians should approach potentially sensitive topics delicately and avoid being confrontational by opening with a term like “addiction” and requesting that the patient fill out a questionnaire before obtaining consent to be screened.

E) INCORRECT:

While there is a correlation between higher rates of hypertension and Native American ancestry, it has not yet been established whether this is a socially determined health risk (e.g., diet), a genetic predisposition, or the result of confounders (e.g., inadequate health care availability). At this time, there is no recommendation for intensified screening for hypertension in Native American persons. Furthermore, there is no reason to suspect hypertension in this patient who has normal blood pressure measurements.
questions.hint: Social determinants of health are an important factor to consider during routine health maintenance examinations.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician for an annual health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her boyfriend. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her mother had ovarian cancer at the age of 52 years. The patient does not drink alcohol or take illicit drugs. Vaccinations are up-to-date. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 72 kg (159 lb); BMI 26 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate health maintenance recommendation at this time?

choices.text: Perform nucleic acid amplification testing for chlamydia and gonorrhea

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This woman meets the criteria identified by the USPSTF for the screening of a condition that is common among individuals in her age group and should receive testing at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

In asymptomatic patients, urine culture is only recommended by the USPSTF for the screening of asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnant individuals. Asymptomatic bacteriuria does not usually result in symptomatic infection, so the USPSTF recommends against this screening in nonpregnant adults. Screening may result in overtreatment, increasing the risk of patients developing adverse effects from antibiotic therapy and raising the risk of emergence of antibiotic-resistant bacteria.

C) INCORRECT:

Serum CA-125 concentration can be used in the evaluation of a patient with an adnexal mass or to monitor disease progression or recurrence of treatment in patients with ovarian cancer. Although this patient has a first-degree relative with ovarian cancer, which thereby increases her risk of developing ovarian cancer, serum CA-125 concentration measurement is not recommended for screening of ovarian cancer in asymptomatic patients. Patients with a high-risk family history should rather be referred to genetic counseling.

D) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends cervical cancer screening with high-risk HPV testing (hrHPV test) every 5 years in all women > 30 years of age; the American Cancer Society recommends primary HPV testing every 5 years for women 25–65 years of age. In young women, HPV infections tend to be transient and resolve without treatment, and testing in this age group results in a considerable false-positive rate, which can lead to unnecessary invasive procedures (e.g., cervical biopsy, loop excision, conization). In women younger than 21 years old, such as this patient, the USPSTF recommends against cervical cancer screening as the harms outweigh the benefits.

E) CORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends screening for N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis infections in all sexually active women < 25 years of age and in women ≥ 25 years of age with specific risk factors (e.g., women with new or multiple sex partners). N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis infections are often asymptomatic in women but can result in complications such as pelvic inflammatory disease and infertility. Screening consists of nucleic acid amplification tests of the urine, which have both high sensitivity and specificity for these infections. Although there is not a defined screening interval, it is reasonable to annually repeat the screening in women with new or persistent risk factors.

F) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends cervical cancer screening by PAP smear every 3 years for all women between 21 and 65 years of age. In women younger than 21 years old, such as this patient, cervical cancer is rare and screening might result in false-positive results, which may lead to unnecessary invasive procedures (e.g., cervical biopsy, loop excision, conization). Some of these procedures increase the risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes (e.g., preterm delivery). Because evidence shows that the harms of cervical cancer screening in women younger than 21 years of age outweigh the benefits, the USPSTF recommends against screening in this age group.
questions.hint: The United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends screening for a condition that is common in sexually active women < 25 years of age.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the office to establish care after moving to the area from a different state with her husband and 3 children. She has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), hypertension, and constipation. Her current medication includes valsartan, salmeterol, and a fiber supplement for constipation. She entered menopause last year. Four years ago, she underwent hemorrhoidectomy; a sigmoidoscopy at that time showed no abnormalities. Her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 66 years; the patient's last mammogram from 6 months ago was normal. Her last primary HPV test taken 3 years ago was negative. She does not drink alcohol. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years but quit 8 years ago when she was diagnosed with COPD. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows varicose veins in the lower extremities. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable for her age. Which of the following screening studies is most appropriate at this time?

choices.text: Low-dose CT scan of the chest

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Annual low-dose CT scan of the chest is indicated for lung cancer screening in adults aged 50 to 80 years who have a smoking history ≥ 20 pack years. Screening recommendations for former smokers vary. Although the American Cancer Society supports screening regardless of time since last smoked, some organizations (e.g., USPSTF) recommend limiting screening to individuals who have smoked within the past 15 years.

See “Screening for cancer” and “Screening recommendations for nonpregnant women by age” tables.

B) INCORRECT:

The USPSTF recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). The previously recommended age to start screening was 50 years. Sigmoidoscopy every 5 years is an appropriate strategy. Because this patient had her last sigmoidoscopy 4 years ago, which was normal, and lacks symptoms suggestive of colorectal cancer (e.g., weight loss, hematochezia), sigmoidoscopy is not indicated at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Mammography is indicated for the screening of breast cancer in women aged 40–74 years. According to the latest 2024 USPSTF recommendation, mammography should be repeated every 2 years. This patient had a mammogram 6 months ago with normal findings and does not require any further testing right now.

D) INCORRECT:

According to the USPSTF recommendation, Pap smear is indicated for the screening of cervical cancer in women aged 21 to 65 years. Pap smear should be performed every 3 years if done alone, or every 5 years when performed as co-testing. Alternatively, in patients aged 30 to 65 years, the FDA-approved primary HPV tests performed every 5 years are sufficient for cervical cancer screening. This patient had HPV testing 3 years ago and does not require any further testing at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasonography is used to screen for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) and is recommended in men 65–75 years of age who have a smoking history. Screening can also be considered in women 65–75 years of age who have a smoking history, in individuals < 65 years of age with multiple risk factors for AAA and/or a family history of AAA, and in individuals 65–75 years of age with a positive family history for AAA in a first-degree relative. Based on this patient's sex, age, and risk factors, screening for a different condition with another modality is indicated at this time.
questions.hint: This screening study is recommended by the United States Preventative Services Task Force (USPSTF) in adults aged 50 to 80 years.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the office as a new patient. Two weeks ago, she gave birth to a healthy girl. Vaginal delivery was uncomplicated and mother and child were discharged after 3 days. Since the delivery of the child, the patient has had vaginal discharge that changed color from red to yellow. She has no pain with urination. She says that she has not been getting much sleep since her daughter's birth and often feels tired. She has not had depressed mood or excessive worrying. The child is exclusively breastfed. The patient has a history of well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. She used to take metformin that was switched to insulin during pregnancy. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. She lives with her husband, two children, and the newborn in a small town in Wyoming. Her only sexual partner is her husband. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows bilaterally engorged, slightly tender breasts with erythematous nipples and a firm, nontender uterine fundus palpable at the height of the symphysis. There are yellowish stains on the perineal pad. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Offer referral to a weight loss program
Screen for emotional and physical partner violence

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Referral to a weight loss program or other behavioral interventions is recommended by the US Preventive Services Task Force for patients with a BMI of 30 kg/m2 or higher to prevent obesity-related morbidity and mortality. This patient has a BMI of 27 kg/m2.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone levels are indicated to evaluate for thyroid disorders such as postpartum thyroiditis. Although postpartum thyroiditis can manifest with fatigue, other features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., weight loss, palpitations, intolerance to heat) or hypothyroidism (e.g., cold intolerance, constipation) would be expected as well. Furthermore, postpartum thyroiditis is typically associated with type 1 diabetes mellitus, not type 2.

C) CORRECT:

The US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends screening all women of reproductive age for intimate partner violence (IPV). According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), in the US, a little under 50% of women and men experience IPV during their lifetime. The risk of IPV increases during pregnancy and the postpartum period. Screening can help to address immediate threats and prevent long-term IPV-associated conditions (e.g., posttraumatic stress disorder). To screen for IPV, the physician can ask a single nonjudgmental and nonstigmatizing question (e.g., “Some of the patients I see have been hurt or threatened by someone close to them. Is this something that you have experienced?”). IPV screening tools include the HARK questions, HITS screening tool, and STaT questions. Management of IPV includes immediate and, most importantly, ongoing support.

The USPSTF does not recommend routine screening for IPV in other patient groups (men, women not of reproductive age, vulnerable individuals, older adults) because of a lack of evidence that such interventions provide any benefit to these patients. Other sources do recommend screening for IPV in these patient groups because of an absence of harm and a potential benefit. The WHO recommends targeted screening for patients with red flags for IPV.

D) INCORRECT:

Urine culture is indicated in the diagnostic workup of urinary tract infections (UTIs) in select cases (e.g., uncomplicated lower UTI if urinalysis is negative but suspicion persists, complicated lower UTI, suspected upper UTI). This patient has no signs of UTI (e.g., dysuria, fever) and her vaginal discharge is most consistent with normal lochia. In patients with suspected sexually transmitted infection (e.g., patients with thick yellow, malodorous vaginal discharge), other tests would be indicated (e.g., nucleic acid amplification test, vaginal smear).

E) INCORRECT:

Behavioral counseling on sexually transmitted infections (STIs) is recommended by the US Preventive Services Task Force for all sexually active adolescents and for adults at increased risk of STIs (e.g., who do not consistently use condoms and have several sexual partners). This patient is not part of either of these groups.
questions.hint: This patient is from Wyoming but the following step in management applies to all women of reproductive age in the US when they come to the office as a new patient.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination after starting a new job as a marketing manager. She feels well. Her medical history is remarkable for hypertension treated with ramipril, and prediabetes well-controlled with diet and exercise. She had asthma during childhood but has not required treatment since the age of 14 years. Last year, she had a kidney stone that passed spontaneously. Four years ago, she had a mammogram and a colonoscopy, which showed no abnormalities. She is sexually active with her husband only. She has no children. Menopause occurred at the age of 51 years. Her mother was diagnosed with renal cancer at the age of 69 years. She smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for 12 years but quit 17 years ago. She drinks one to two glasses of wine nightly. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 78 kg (172 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 131/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. At this time, screening for which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Annual lung cancer screening with a low-dose CT scan is recommended for individuals aged 50–80 years who have a smoking history of ≥ 20 pack-year. Although this patient is 54 years old and a former smoker, she only has a 12-pack-year smoking history, which makes her unsuitable for lung cancer screening at this time.

B) CORRECT:

For women with an average risk of breast cancer, the USPSTF recommends mammography screening every 2 years starting no later than 40 years of age. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists and American Cancer Society also recommend starting screening mammography at 40 years of age and advise clinicians to consider screening annually rather than biennially. Because this patient is 54 years of age, and her last mammogram was 4 years ago, she is due for breast cancer screening.

See “Cancer screening” table.

C) INCORRECT:

According to the USPSTF, colorectal cancer screening with colonoscopy is recommended for all average-risk individuals aged 45–75 years every 10 years. Since this patient has no known risk factors for colorectal cancer (e.g., family history of colorectal cancer or hereditary cancer syndromes, personal history of adenomatous polyps, colorectal cancer, or inflammatory bowel disease) and her last colonoscopy performed 4 years ago showed no abnormalities, she does not require colorectal cancer screening at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) screening may be considered in patients who have a high risk of developing hereditary RCC (e.g., personal or family history of Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome). Although this patient's mother had RCC, the timing of her diagnosis suggests a sporadic, rather than hereditary, case of RCC, and puts this patient in an average, rather than a high-risk group for RCC. There is no routine RCC screening currently recommended for average-risk individuals.

E) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic cancer screening may be considered in patients who have a high risk of developing hereditary pancreatic cancer (e.g., personal or family history of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome). Although this patient has a number of predisposing factors for pancreatic cancer (e.g., smoking history, overweight, prediabetes, alcohol consumption), she has no personal or family history of any hereditary cancer syndromes and is therefore in an average, rather than a high-risk group for pancreatic cancer. There is no routine pancreatic cancer screening currently recommended for average-risk individuals.
questions.hint: The United States Preventive Services Taskforce (USPSTF) recommends screening for this type of cancer between 40 and 74 years of age.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because they are concerned about her desire to adopt a strict vegan diet. She has been a vegetarian ever since she watched a documentary about industrial livestock farming. Last month, she joined a group of friends who toured a dairy farm in their neighboring village in Montana, which convinced her to become a vegan and consume only unprocessed foods. She eats a well-balanced diet rich in vegetables, fruits, seeds, and nuts. The parents are concerned that she will not get enough nutrition. The patient just finished her soccer season and plans on joining the ski team for the winter season next month. She has no history of serious medical illness and takes no medications. She is annoyed about the concerns of her parents and believes a vegan diet will not only help save animal lives but also protect the planet. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 60 kg (132 Ib); BMI is 23 kg/m2. The physician should counsel the patient that without supplements, she is at increased risk of developing which of the following nutritional deficiency?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although folate can be found in meat (especially liver), the main sources of folate are leafy green vegetables. It is highly unlikely that this girl will develop folate deficiency after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet. Important causes of folate deficiency include severe malnutrition (e.g., “tea and toast” diet, chronic alcohol use), malabsorption (e.g., intestinal resection, celiac disease), increased folate demand (e.g., pregnancy, hemolytic anemia), and medication use (e.g., methotrexate, phenytoin).

B) INCORRECT:

Fiber is found in a large number of fruits (e.g., prunes, apples), vegetables (e.g., beans, lentils), and grains (e.g., oatmeal, wheat). It is highly unlikely this girl will develop fiber deficiency after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet.

C) INCORRECT:

Although phenylalanine, an essential amino acid, is mainly found in animal products, such as meat, eggs, and dairy, it can also be found in plant-based products such as nuts, soybean, squash, and wheat. It is unlikely this girl will develop deficiency of any amino acids after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet.

D) INCORRECT:

Although vitamin B6 can be found in meat (especially poultry and liver), the main sources of vitamin B6 are nuts, whole grains, and vegetables. It is highly unlikely this girl will develop vitamin B6 deficiency after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet. Important causes of vitamin B6 deficiency include severe malnutrition, chronic alcohol use, and medication use (e.g., isoniazid, hydralazine).

E) CORRECT:

People who follow a vegan diet have a higher risk of developing vitamin D deficiency compared to the general population. This is due to the fact that a vegan diet does not include dairy, which is a major dietary source of vitamin D. Therefore, individuals who transition to a vegan diet should be advised to consume sufficient amounts of vitamin D-fortified foods (e.g., plant-based milk alternatives, cereal, juices) to achieve the recommended daily dose of vitamin D. They should also be counseled on the importance of exposure to sunlight, another major source of vitamin D, to boost the endogenous production of vitamin D, which is often deficient in individuals who live in northern latitudes (like this patient from Montana), especially during the Winter season.

Apart from vitamin D, a vegan diet is often deficient in calcium, vitamin B12, and iron. Patients should be counseled on supplementation to avoid nutritional deficiencies.
questions.hint: A vegan diet excludes all meat and animal products such as milk and milk products.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man is referred to a radiology practice by his primary care physician for a CT scan because of a 2-month history of progressive dyspnea, cough, and hemoptysis. The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years but quit 3 years ago. The CT scan shows a 3-cm nodule with irregular borders in the right upper lobe suggestive of malignancy. The radiologist who reviewed the CT scan writes the final report and uploads it to the patient's electronic health record. Because some of the front office staff in the primary care physician's practice had been out on sick leave, the patient's follow-up visit was rescheduled to 4 weeks later. When the physician finally discusses the results with the patient, the patient becomes angry and says, “I have been unable to sleep for the past month because I was so worried about the results, and now I will die because I didn't receive treatment in time.” Which of the following strategies would have been most effective in preventing the delay in further management?

choices.text: Computerized alert notifications for the primary care physician upon uploading of the radiology report
Explanation of the imaging findings to the patient by the radiologist in person
Sending concrete follow-up recommendations and a compact disc of the images to the primary care physician via registered mail
Verbal communication of imaging results between the providers via phone
Asking the patient to contact the primary care physician's practice weekly until the imaging results are available

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alert notifications can help physicians receive critical results in a timely manner. However, because physicians often receive an increased amount of notifications, they may not read all alerts and fail to acknowledge critical results (alert fatigue).

B) INCORRECT:

The radiologist may explain critical findings to a patient if the referring physician cannot be contacted in a timely manner or if management will be affected because of delays. However, because the referring physician will provide further management and has also likely built a trusting relationship with the patient, critical test results should be communicated by them whenever possible.

C) INCORRECT:

Follow-up recommendations (e.g., additional diagnostic studies) by the interpreting physician can help the referring physician plan further management. However, mailing records is not the fastest or most efficient method and would not have prevented delays in management. In general, electronic communication of critical imaging results is preferred over paper-based reporting.

D) CORRECT:

In addition to the electronically sent report, critical imaging results should be delivered through additional means of communication that ensure timely receipt of the findings. Verbal communication between providers, either in person or via phone, is recommended as it allows the receiving physician to acknowledge receipt of the information, facilitates further discussion, and is likely to prompt timely follow-up actions. Any additional communication between providers should be properly documented (e.g., method of communication, name of the person who received the information).

Patients should be informed about the manner and time in which they can expect test results to be communicated to them, and should also be made aware of what to do if they do not receive the results in the expected time frame.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients should be informed about the manner and time in which they can expect test results to be communicated to them, and should also be made aware of what to do if they do not receive the results in the expected time frame. However, telling a patient to contact the primary care physician's practice weekly places all responsibility for follow-up on the patient. The referring physician is responsible for obtaining the results of the tests ordered and communicating them with the patient in a timely manner.
questions.hint: To ensure the quality of care and avoid patient harm, critical imaging results should be communicated with the referring physician in a timely manner.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother for contraceptive counseling. The patient's mother has already discussed different contraceptive options with her. The mother says, “Most teenagers her age are already engaging in sexual intercourse, so it's about time my daughter got protection. She has plans to go to college and cannot have a baby at this point.” The patient has no history of serious illness. She feels well but appears uncomfortable during the conversation. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The physician asks the mother to leave the room for the patient's privacy. After the physician initiates a conversation about contraception, the patient reveals that she wants to start engaging in sexual activity with her girlfriend. The patient has not been sexually active before. She says that she is afraid to tell her parents because they oppose same-sex relationships. Which of the following is the most appropriate next action by the physician?

choices.text: Ask the mother's permission to educate the patient about safer sex practices
Tell the patient to disclose her sexual orientation to her mother
Screen for chlamydia and gonorrhea infection

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

All adolescents should be counseled on safer sex practices and contraception. Barrier protection, such as dental dams and condoms, should be recommended to individuals engaging in same-sex sexual activity. Oral contraception is not necessary for individuals in monogamous same-sex relationships.

B) INCORRECT:

Most treatment decisions for minors require parental consent. However, in most states, sexual health care (e.g., contraception, STI testing, pregnancy care except for abortion) is exempt from this rule. Therefore, asking the mother for permission to provide education on sexual health topics is not required.

C) INCORRECT:

Open communication between parents and their children about sexual health and relationships can have a positive impact on behavior (e.g., increased use of safer sex practices). However, some parents may not accept their children's sexual orientation and disclosure could create family conflict. Therefore, health care providers should discuss family dynamics with patients before giving advice, especially if patients indicate that their parents may disapprove of their sexual orientation.

D) INCORRECT:

Screening for chlamydia and gonorrhea is recommended in all sexually active women ≤ 24 years of age and in all sexually-active women > 24 years of age with risk factors for STIs. This patient has not yet been sexually active and has thus not been exposed to risk factors for STI. While screening for these infections is recommended once the patient becomes sexually active, a different step in management is indicated at this point.

E) CORRECT:

All adolescents, regardless of their sexual orientation, should receive the recommended vaccinations for their age group. HPV vaccination should be administered before the onset of sexual activity in a 2-dose regimen for patients aged 9–14 years and in a 3-dose regimen for patients ≥ 15 years. In addition to counseling on vaccinations, pregnancy, and safer sex practices (e.g., the use of barrier protection, such as dental dams), the physician should foster a trusting relationship in which the minor can openly communicate about sexuality, sexual orientation, and gender identity and be informed about their options for receiving confidential care. Open communication between parents and their children about sexual health and relationships can have a positive impact on behavior (e.g., increased use of safer sex practices) and should be encouraged by physicians. However, because some parents may not accept their children's sexual orientation, health care providers should discuss family dynamics with patients before giving advice.
questions.hint: Adolescents should be counseled on the prevention of sexually transmitted infections, pregnancy, and substance use, regardless of their sexual orientation or gender identity.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is brought to the office by her parents because they are concerned about her desire to adopt a strict vegan diet. She eats a well-balanced diet rich in vegetables, fruits, seeds, and nuts. She has no history of serious medical illness and takes no medications. The patient should be counseled that without supplements, there is an increased risk of developing which of the following nutritional deficiency?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although folate can be found in meat (especially liver), the main sources of folate are leafy green vegetables. It is highly unlikely that this patient will develop folate deficiency after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet. Important causes of folate deficiency include severe malnutrition (e.g., “tea and toast” diet), malabsorption (e.g., intestinal resection, celiac disease), increased folate demand (e.g., pregnancy, hemolytic anemia), and medication use (e.g., methotrexate, phenytoin).

B) INCORRECT:

Fiber is found in a large number of fruits (e.g., prunes, apples), vegetables (e.g., beans, lentils), and grains (e.g., oatmeal, wheat). It is highly unlikely this patient will develop fiber deficiency after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet.

C) INCORRECT:

Although phenylalanine, an essential amino acid, is mainly found in animal products, such as meat, eggs, and dairy, it can also be found in plant-based sources such as nuts, soybean, squash, and wheat. It is unlikely this patient will develop deficiency of any amino acids after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet.

D) INCORRECT:

Although vitamin B6 can be found in meat (especially poultry and liver), the main sources of vitamin B6 are nuts, whole grains, and vegetables. It is highly unlikely this patient will develop vitamin B6 deficiency after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet. Important causes of vitamin B6 deficiency include severe malnutrition, chronic alcohol use, and medication use (e.g., isoniazid, hydralazine).

E) CORRECT:

People who follow a vegan diet have a higher risk of developing vitamin D deficiency compared to the general population. This is due to the fact that a vegan diet does not include dairy, which is a major dietary source of vitamin D. Therefore, individuals who transition to a vegan diet should be advised to consume sufficient amounts of vitamin D-fortified foods (e.g., plant-based milk alternatives, cereal, juices) to achieve the recommended daily dose of vitamin D. They should also be counseled on the importance of exposure to sunlight, another major source of vitamin D, to boost the endogenous production of vitamin D.

Apart from vitamin D, a vegan diet is often deficient in calcium, vitamin B12, and iron. Patients should be counseled on supplementation to avoid nutritional deficiencies.
questions.hint: A vegan diet excludes all meat and animal products such as milk and milk products.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman presents for a routine health maintenance examination. She has no history of serious illness. Colonoscopy 4 years ago disclosed no abnormalities. A serum lipid profile obtained last year was within the reference range. Two years ago, a Pap smear with testing for human papillomavirus showed no abnormalities. Mammography performed 10 months ago showed no abnormalities. Her father developed colon cancer at the age of 75 years. She has no family history of hip fracture. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?

choices.text: No specific health maintenance recommendation is needed

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Screening for lipid disorders is recommended in all adults aged 20–75 years at least every 4–6 years. In adults aged 40–75 years, the screening interval can be shortened based on the individual ASCVD risk. Given that this patient had a normal serum lipid profile 1 year ago and has no significant risk factors for cardiovascular disease (e.g., history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, or smoking), her ASCVD risk is likely low. A repeat serum lipid profile is not warranted at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). Colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Individuals with a first-degree relative (FDR) with a history of colorectal cancer, like this patient, are generally recommended to obtain screening more frequently (every 5 years) and start earlier (40 years of age or 10 years before the youngest FDR's age at diagnosis). Because her last colonoscopy 4 years ago was normal and she lacks symptoms suggestive of colorectal cancer (e.g., weight loss, hematochezia), she does not require repeat screening at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening women ≥ 65 years of age for osteoporosis with bone measurement testing (e.g., dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry). For postmenopausal women < 65 years of age, the decision to screen should be based on an assessment of the patient's overall risk for osteoporosis. This patient has no significant risk factors for osteoporosis (e.g., family history of hip fracture, smoking, alcohol consumption, low BMI), so screening is not indicated at this time.

D) CORRECT:

No specific health maintenance recommendation is needed at this time for this 61-year-old woman who is currently up to date with all recommended screening tests based on her age, history, and physical examination findings. The recommendations that this patient has followed include screening for cervical cancer (Pap smear and human papillomavirus testing every 5 years), colon cancer (every 5 years in patients with a first-degree relative with a history of colorectal cancer, every 10 years in the general population), and breast cancer (mammography every 1–2 years). Moreover, she does not have identifiable risk factors for cardiovascular disease (e.g., history of dyslipidemia, diabetes, hypertension, or smoking) or osteoporosis (e.g., family history of hip fracture, smoking, alcohol consumption, low BMI), which would warrant enhanced screening for these conditions.

See “Screening recommendations for nonpregnant women by age” table.

E) INCORRECT:

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening women between 30 and 65 years of age for cervical cancer using any of the following strategies: every 3 years with cervical cytology, every 5 years with testing for high-risk human papillomavirus (hrHPV) testing, or every 5 years with hrHPV testing in combination with cytology. This patient had a normal Pap smear with testing for human papillomavirus 2 years ago, so she does not require further screening at this time.
questions.hint: This patient's history and physical examination findings do not suggest that she has a higher risk of morbidity than average.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the office in June for a routine check-up. She has chronic back pain. Her last mammogram was 6 months ago and showed no abnormalities. Her last Pap smear was 2 years ago and unremarkable. A colonoscopy 5 years ago was normal. She takes a multivitamin daily and uses topical steroids. Her immunization records show that she has never received a pneumococcal or a shingles vaccine, her last tetanus booster was 6 years ago, and her last influenza vaccine was 2 years ago. BMI is 26 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteoporosis screening is performed with dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA). The bone density scan is recommended for postmenopausal women older than 65 years of age, or younger postmenopausal women with a pathological fracture or other risk factors for osteoporosis (e.g., positive family history).

B) INCORRECT:

The CDC recommends pneumococcal vaccination for adults ≥ 50 years of age. However, the polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23) is typically recommended after administering a pneumococcal conjugate vaccine, which this patient has not yet received.

C) INCORRECT:

A Pap smear is recommended every 3 years in women 21–65 years of age (or even better for patients 30–65 years of age, HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years). This woman had a normal Pap smear 2 years ago.

D) INCORRECT:

Because influenza viruses are constantly evolving, the influenza vaccine composition is reviewed, and a newly updated vaccine is released (and recommended) for every flu season (∼ Oct.–Apr. in the northern hemisphere). This patient should return again in the early fall for an influenza vaccine.

E) CORRECT:

The CDC currently recommends the recombinant zoster vaccine for the prevention of herpes zoster (shingles) and its related complications. The recombinant zoster vaccine (administered in 2 doses, 2–6 months apart) is recommended for all immunocompetent adults ≥ 50 years of age, regardless of a history of shingles, and for adults ≥ 19 years of age who are or will become immunodeficient or immunosuppressed due to disease or therapy.

Additionally, this individual should receive pneumococcal vaccination with a pneumococcal conjugate vaccine.
questions.hint: The correct choice is recommended in all patients over 50 years by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the office as a new patient. Two weeks ago, she gave birth to a healthy girl via uncomplicated vaginal delivery. Since the delivery of the child, the patient has had vaginal discharge that changed color from red to yellow. She has no pain with urination. She says that she has not been getting much sleep since her daughter's birth and often feels tired but has not had depressed mood or excessive worrying. She lives with her husband, two children, and the newborn in a small town. Her only sexual partner is her husband. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals engorged, slightly tender breasts with erythematous nipples and a firm, nontender uterine fundus palpable at the level of the symphysis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Offer referral to a weight loss program
Screen for emotional and physical partner violence

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Referral to a weight loss program or other behavioral interventions is recommended by the US Preventive Services Task Force for patients with a BMI of 30 kg/m2 or higher to prevent obesity-related morbidity and mortality. This patient has a BMI of 27 kg/m2.

B) INCORRECT:

Urine culture is indicated in the diagnostic workup of urinary tract infections (UTIs) in select cases (e.g., uncomplicated lower UTI if urinalysis is negative but suspicion persists, complicated lower UTI, suspected upper UTI). This patient has no signs of UTI (e.g., dysuria, fever) and her vaginal discharge is most consistent with normal lochia. In patients with suspected sexually transmitted infection (e.g., patients with thick yellow, malodorous vaginal discharge), other tests would be indicated (e.g., nucleic acid amplification test, vaginal smear).

C) INCORRECT:

Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone levels are indicated to evaluate for thyroid disorders such as postpartum thyroiditis. Although postpartum thyroiditis can manifest with fatigue, other features of hyperthyroidism (e.g., weight loss, palpitations, intolerance to heat) or hypothyroidism (e.g., cold intolerance, constipation) would be expected as well.

D) INCORRECT:

Behavioral counseling on sexually transmitted infections (STIs) is recommended by the US Preventive Services Task Force for all sexually active adolescents and for adults at increased risk of STIs (e.g., who do not consistently use condoms and have several sexual partners). This patient is not part of either of these groups.

E) CORRECT:

The US Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends screening all women of reproductive age for intimate partner violence (IPV). According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), in the US, a little under 50% of women and men experience IPV during their lifetime. The risk of IPV increases during pregnancy and the postpartum period. Screening can help to address immediate threats and prevent long-term IPV-associated conditions (e.g., posttraumatic stress disorder). To screen for IPV, the clinician can ask a single nonjudgmental and nonstigmatizing question (e.g., “Some of the patients I see have been hurt or threatened by someone close to them. Is this something that you have experienced?”). IPV screening tools include the HARK questions, HITS screening tool, and STaT questions. Management of IPV includes immediate and, most importantly, ongoing support.

The USPSTF does not recommend routine screening for IPV in other patient groups (men, women not of reproductive age, vulnerable individuals, older adults) because of a lack of evidence that such interventions provide any benefit to these patients. Other sources do recommend screening for IPV in these patient groups because of an absence of harm and a potential benefit. The WHO recommends targeted screening for patients with red flags for IPV.
questions.hint: The following step in management applies to all women of reproductive age in the US when they come to the office as a new patient.

questions.text: A 36-year-old Native American man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. The patient is married, has 4 children, and works as a software engineer. His father died in a car accident and his mother has coronary artery disease. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 92 kg (203 lbs); his BMI is 28 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 121/78 mm Hg on the right arm and 122/80 mm Hg on the left. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement by the clinician regarding health maintenance at this visit?

choices.text: “I would like to perform a fecal occult blood test on a stool sample.”
“I suggest we do a 24-hour blood pressure measurement to evaluate you for hypertension.”
“I would like to discuss screening options for high blood sugar with you today.”
“At this time, there is nothing to worry about. Have a great day.”
“Please fill out a short questionnaire about addictions before you leave today.”

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While there is a correlation between higher rates of colorectal cancer and Native American ancestry, the causes of this are complex and not fully established. Inequities in access to colorectal screening may be the primary driver for this disparity. The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). Colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Since this patient is only 36 years of age and does not have significant risk factors for colorectal cancer, screening is not currently indicated. In addition, it is inappropriate to tell this patient he has a high risk of malignancy without providing context, as it will likely increase patient anxiety.

B) INCORRECT:

While there is a correlation between higher rates of hypertension and Native American ancestry, it has not yet been established whether this is a socially determined health risk (e.g., diet), a genetic predisposition, or the result of confounders (e.g., inadequate health care availability). At this time, there is no recommendation for intensified screening for hypertension in Native American persons. Furthermore, there is no reason to suspect hypertension in this patient who has normal blood pressure measurements.

C) CORRECT:

The American Diabetes Association (ADA) recommends screening for type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in individuals ≥ 35 years of age regardless of risk factors and in individuals < 35 years of age with either overweight or obesity and ≥ 1 additional risk factor for T2DM (e.g., first-degree family history, certain race or ethnicity, hypertension). The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for T2DM in asymptomatic individuals 35–70 years of age with overweight obesity. As per both guidelines, screening this patient for T2DM is recommended.

Native American individuals have the highest prevalence of T2DM among racial and ethnic groups in the United States as a result of genetic and socioeconomic factors. While smoking, diet, and alcohol use are risk factors that are generally assessed in routine health maintenance examinations, social and genetic determinants of health are less commonly assessed, often because of poor access to care and provider negligence of minority groups. Poor screening consequently contributes to a higher burden of disease among various racial and ethnic minorities (e.g., African Americans, Hispanics, and Asian Americans).

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation is normal as he has no complaints and a normal physical examination. However, Native American ancestry is associated with an increased risk for certain conditions, and patients within this population should receive the corresponding counseling and screening necessary. Furthermore, it is recommended that, prior to the end of the visit, the clinician reminds the patient to schedule an appropriate follow-up appointment.

E) INCORRECT:

While recreational drug and alcohol use are a matter of concern in Native American communities, it is inappropriate to assume an addiction from this patient's race alone. The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends that all adults should be screened for excessive alcohol use, but since this patient reports not drinking alcohol or taking recreational drugs, additional screening is unwarranted. Moreover, clinicians should approach potentially sensitive topics delicately and avoid being confrontational by opening with a term like “addiction” and requesting that the patient fill out a questionnaire before obtaining consent to be screened.
questions.hint: Social determinants of health are an important factor to consider during routine health maintenance examinations.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is referred to a radiology practice by his primary care provider for a CT scan because of a 2-month history of progressive dyspnea, cough, and hemoptysis. The CT scan shows a 3-cm nodule with irregular borders in the right upper lobe suggestive of malignancy. The radiologist who reviewed the CT scan writes the final report and uploads it to the patient's electronic health record. Because some of the front office staff in the primary care provider's practice had been out on sick leave, the patient's follow-up visit was rescheduled to 4 weeks later. When the clinician finally discusses the results with the patient, the patient becomes angry and says, “I have been unable to sleep for the past month because I was so worried about the results, and now I will die because I didn't receive treatment in time.” Which of the following strategies would have been most effective in preventing the delay in further management?

choices.text: Computerized alert notifications for the primary care provider upon uploading of the radiology report
Asking the patient to contact the primary care provider's practice weekly until the imaging results are available
Verbal communication of critical imaging results between the providers via phone
Sending concrete follow-up recommendations and a compact disc of the images to the primary care provider via registered mail
Explanation of the imaging findings to the patient by the radiologist in person

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alert notifications can help clinicians receive critical results in a timely manner. However, because clinicians often receive an increased amount of notifications, they may not read all alerts and fail to acknowledge critical results (alert fatigue).

B) INCORRECT:

Patients should be informed about the manner and time in which they can expect test results to be communicated to them, and should also be made aware of what to do if they do not receive the results in the expected time frame. However, telling a patient to contact the primary care provider's practice weekly places all responsibility for follow-up on the patient. The referring clinician is responsible for obtaining the results of the tests ordered and communicating them with the patient in a timely manner.

C) CORRECT:

In addition to the electronically sent report, critical imaging results should be delivered through additional means of communication that ensure timely receipt of the findings. Verbal communication between providers, either in person or via phone, is recommended as it allows the receiving clinician to acknowledge receipt of the information, facilitates further discussion, and is likely to prompt timely follow-up actions. Any additional communication between providers should be properly documented (e.g., method of communication, name of the person who received the information).

Patients should be informed about the manner and time in which they can expect test results to be communicated to them, and should also be made aware of what to do if they do not receive the results in the expected time frame.

D) INCORRECT:

Follow-up recommendations (e.g., additional diagnostic studies) by the interpreting clinician can help the referring clinician plan further management. However, mailing records is not the fastest or most efficient method and would not have prevented delays in management. In general, electronic communication of critical imaging results is preferred over paper-based reporting.

E) INCORRECT:

The radiologist may explain critical findings to a patient if the referring clinician cannot be contacted in a timely manner or if management will be affected because of delays. However, because the referring clinician will provide further management and has also likely built a trusting relationship with the patient, critical test results should be communicated by them whenever possible.
questions.hint: To ensure the quality of care and avoid patient harm, critical imaging results should be communicated with the referring clinician in a timely manner.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman at 12 weeks’ gestation undergoes testing for an infectious disease known to cause neonatal complications. Upon positive results, she receives timely treatment to prevent disease progression and transmission. Which prevention strategy does this most accurately represent?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tertiary prevention targets reducing long-term disability and managing complications in advanced disease states. The scenario involves early detection and treatment to prevent progression and transmission, aligning with secondary prevention rather than managing established complications.

B) INCORRECT:

Quaternary prevention protects against unnecessary medical interventions and overmedicalization. The scenario involves proactive management of a confirmed infection with evidence-based treatment to prevent complications, focusing on timely diagnosis and treatment rather than limiting unnecessary care.

C) CORRECT:

Secondary prevention involves early detection and prompt intervention to halt disease progression and prevent complications. In this scenario, testing during early pregnancy identifies an infectious disease that could lead to neonatal complications if untreated. The timely initiation of treatment reduces morbidity and minimizes the risk of vertical transmission. This approach exemplifies secondary prevention by addressing a known, early-stage disease before significant harm occurs.

Key learning point: Secondary prevention involves early detection and treatment of diseases to prevent progression and complications, such as screening for hepatitis B in pregnant women to prevent transmission to the newborn.

D) INCORRECT:

Primary prevention aims to prevent disease occurrence before exposure or infection, such as through immunization or risk factor education. Here, the patient is already infected, and the intervention focuses on early management rather than preventing the disease from occurring, distinguishing it from primary prevention.

questions.text: You are a public health physician in a rural northern public health unit. Over two weeks, eight cases of pertussis have been reported, but local clinic logs suggest fifty children have been treated for a prolonged cough consistent with pertussis. You require accurate, timely data to guide targeted immunization. Which one of the following is the best next step to investigate the outbreak?

choices.text: Active surveillance with daily clinic calls.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Electronic laboratory reporting improves the speed of case reporting after confirmation but captures only lab-confirmed cases, missing clinically diagnosed cases and introducing delays from test processing, which limits comprehensiveness and timeliness during a fast-moving outbreak.

B) INCORRECT:

Syndromic surveillance tracks symptom-based visits, such as coughs, to identify patterns suggestive of outbreaks, but lacks the specificity and confirmation required to distinguish pertussis from other causes of cough, making it insufficient for guiding targeted immunization efforts.

C) CORRECT:

Active surveillance with daily outreach is the gold standard for outbreak investigation when passive reporting undercounts cases and delays interventions. By calling clinics each day to identify children with cough lasting more than 14 days or lab-confirmed pertussis, sensitivity increases and reporting lag decreases compared with awaiting routine notifications. Telephone-based contact bypasses barriers to electronic systems in remote settings and promotes provider accountability. Generating near real-time line lists facilitates the identification of transmission hotspots and guides rapid deployment of immunization clinics to unprotected clusters.

Key learning point: Active surveillance is the most effective strategy for rapidly obtaining complete and timely disease data during outbreaks, enabling public health officials to implement targeted interventions.

D) INCORRECT:

Passive physician reminders may modestly increase reporting rates, but still rely on voluntary reporting by providers, resulting in incomplete and delayed data, especially in outbreak situations where active case finding is needed for effective intervention.

E) INCORRECT:

Sentinel surveillance collects information from selected locations, like specific schools, to monitor disease trends over time but does not capture all cases or provide comprehensive outbreak data, limiting its usefulness for immediate responses in small or rural populations.
questions.hint: Surveillance strategies that are most effective for outbreak detection and response enhance data completeness and timeliness.

questions.text: In public health programs aiming for disease elimination, authorities sometimes use a surveillance system that actively seeks and documents cases in communities. Which one of the following best describes this strategy?

choices.text: Mandating that laboratories submit weekly summary statistics.
Publishing disease case counts in public reports.
Regular outreach visits by health workers.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reviewing existing medical records periodically is a retrospective and passive data collection strategy that depends on previous documentation and does not involve direct, systematic outreach to identify new, unrecorded cases within the community.

B) INCORRECT:

Reporting from individuals attending clinics is an example of passive surveillance, where the health system waits for patients or providers to submit information rather than seeking out cases directly; this approach often underestimates true disease incidence, especially for asymptomatic or stigmatized conditions.

C) INCORRECT:

Mandating laboratories to submit weekly summary statistics enhances timeliness and completeness of reporting, but this is a form of enhanced passive surveillance, as it still depends on cases being identified during routine service delivery rather than systematic community case-finding.

D) INCORRECT:

Publishing disease case counts in public reports is a method of disseminating surveillance findings, not an active case-finding strategy, and does not directly contribute to identifying new cases within target populations.

E) CORRECT:

Active surveillance requires regular outreach visits by health workers to identify and document cases that would otherwise remain unreported through passive systems. Health workers screen for symptoms, collect specimens, and record findings during community visits, reducing underreporting essential for the elimination of diseases such as polio and measles. This proactive approach demands logistical resources and fosters trust by addressing language and cultural barriers and engaging local leaders to improve participation and equity.
