Tuberculosis contact tracing in Indigenous and remote communities illustrates active case finding in elimination efforts.

Key learning point: Active surveillance systematically engages the health system to proactively identify and document cases, usually through direct outreach, making it essential for comprehensive disease elimination efforts.
questions.hint: Disease elimination efforts often require maximizing case detection strategies.

questions.text: You are seeing a 16-year-old girl brought to your clinic by her parents, who are concerned about her desire to adopt a strict vegan diet. She reports eating a well-balanced diet that includes vegetables, fruits, seeds, and nuts. She has no history of serious medical illness and does not take any medications. Which one of the following nutritional deficiencies is she at increased risk of developing without supplementation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although folate can be found in meat (especially liver), the main sources of folate are leafy green vegetables. It is highly unlikely that this patient will develop folate deficiency after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet. Important causes of folate deficiency include severe malnutrition (e.g., “tea and toast” diet), malabsorption (e.g., intestinal resection, celiac disease), increased folate demand (e.g., pregnancy, hemolytic anemia), and medication use (e.g., methotrexate, phenytoin).

B) INCORRECT:

Although phenylalanine, an essential amino acid, is mainly found in animal products, such as meat, eggs, and dairy, it can also be found in plant-based sources such as nuts, soybean, squash, and wheat. It is unlikely this patient will develop deficiency of any amino acids after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet.

C) CORRECT:

People who follow a vegan diet have a higher risk of developing vitamin D deficiency compared to the general population. This is due to the fact that a vegan diet does not include dairy, which is a major dietary source of vitamin D. Therefore, individuals who transition to a vegan diet should be advised to consume sufficient amounts of vitamin D-fortified foods (e.g., plant-based milk alternatives, cereal, juices) to achieve the recommended daily dose of vitamin D. They should also be counseled on the importance of exposure to sunlight, another major source of vitamin D, to boost the endogenous production of vitamin D.

Apart from vitamin D, a vegan diet is often deficient in calcium, vitamin B12, and iron. Patients should be counseled on supplementation to avoid nutritional deficiencies.

Key learning point: Vegans are at increased risk for vitamin D deficiency and should ensure adequate intake through fortified foods, supplements, or sunlight exposure.

D) INCORRECT:

Fiber is found in a large number of fruits (e.g., prunes, apples), vegetables (e.g., beans, lentils), and grains (e.g., oatmeal, wheat). It is highly unlikely this patient will develop fiber deficiency after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet.

E) INCORRECT:

Although vitamin B6 can be found in meat (especially poultry and liver), the main sources of vitamin B6 are nuts, whole grains, and vegetables. It is highly unlikely this patient will develop vitamin B6 deficiency after transitioning to a well-balanced vegan diet. Important causes of vitamin B6 deficiency include severe malnutrition, chronic alcohol use, and medication use (e.g., isoniazid, hydralazine).
questions.hint: A vegan diet excludes all meat and animal products such as milk and milk products.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man brings his 6-year-old son for a well-child visit. The father is concerned about his son's future health because he himself was recently diagnosed with hypertension, and his own father had a myocardial infarction at age 52. The child is healthy, meeting all developmental milestones, and has a normal physical examination. The father asks what the most important thing he can do now is to prevent his son from developing heart problems later in life. Which of the following recommendations best exemplifies primordial prevention of cardiovascular disease for this child?

choices.text: Performing genetic testing for familial hypercholesterolemia
Starting statin therapy if his LDL cholesterol is elevated in adolescence
Encouraging a diet rich in fruits and vegetables and regular physical activity
Prescribing low-dose aspirin if he develops type 2 diabetes in adulthood
Initiating annual blood pressure screening starting at age 18

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although genetic testing might be considered due to the family history of premature myocardial infarction, it is a diagnostic tool to identify a pre-existing, inherited risk factor. This is a form of risk assessment, not prevention. Subsequent management based on a positive test would be considered primary prevention, aimed at managing high cholesterol to prevent atherosclerotic disease.

B) INCORRECT:

This is a classic example of primary prevention. It involves treating an established risk factor (elevated LDL cholesterol) with medication to prevent the future development of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. The intervention occurs after the risk factor has already appeared, which is distinct from primordial prevention.

C) CORRECT:

This recommendation is the best example of primordial prevention, which aims to prevent the development of cardiovascular risk factors (e.g., obesity, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes) before they occur. By establishing healthy lifestyle habits in childhood, the goal is to maintain ideal cardiovascular health throughout life and avoid the emergence of risk factors altogether. Due to the child's strong family history of premature cardiovascular disease, instilling these foundational health behaviors at a young age is the most effective long-term strategy to mitigate his future risk.

D) INCORRECT:

This is an example of primary prevention. It describes a strategy to prevent a first cardiovascular event in a person who has developed a significant risk factor (type 2 diabetes). This intervention does not prevent the risk factor from developing, which is the goal of primordial prevention.

E) INCORRECT:

This represents primary or secondary prevention, not primordial. Screening is done to detect an existing risk factor (hypertension) at an early stage so it can be managed. Primordial prevention focuses on preventing the development of hypertension in the first place. Furthermore, routine blood pressure screening is recommended to begin at age 3, not 18.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy from a low-income area is at risk of obesity. His pediatrician discusses community efforts to promote healthy eating from an early age. Which measure best exemplifies primordial prevention?

choices.text: Ban on sugar-sweetened beverages in schools

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Statin therapy addresses existing dyslipidemia, aligning with secondary prevention. Primordial prevention aims to prevent risk factors from emerging by modifying environmental and societal determinants, such as dietary patterns and physical inactivity.

B) INCORRECT:

A weight-loss program targets youth who are already overweight, aligning with secondary or tertiary prevention. Primordial prevention focuses on preventing risk factors from developing by creating environments that promote healthy behaviors.

C) CORRECT:

Primordial prevention aims to prevent the emergence of risk factors by modifying environmental and social conditions. Banning sugar-sweetened beverages in schools reduces children's exposure to added sugars, preventing unhealthy dietary patterns and obesity. This measure addresses the root causes of obesity by shaping healthier community environments, promoting long-term cardiovascular health.

Key learning point: Primordial prevention involves preventing the development of risk factors themselves, rather than managing existing risk factors or disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Annual BMI screening identifies children at risk of obesity, aligning with secondary prevention, which detects risk factors after they develop. Primordial prevention, however, focuses on preventing risk factors from emerging by altering societal and environmental determinants.
